Faster Rates for Compressed Federated Learning with Client-Variance Reduction

Haoyu Zhao Princeton University, NJ (). haoyu@princeton.edu â€ƒâ€ƒ Konstantin Burlachenko KAUST, Saudi Arabia (, ). konstantin.burlachenko@kaust.edu.sa peter.richtarik@kaust.edu.sa â€ƒâ€ƒ Zhize Li Carnegie Mellon University, PA (); Corresponding author. zhizeli@cmu.edu â€ƒâ€ƒ Peter RichtÃ¡rik22footnotemark: 2
Abstract

Due to the communication bottleneck in distributed and federated learning applications, algorithms using communication compression have attracted significant attention and are widely used in practice. Moreover, the huge number, high heterogeneity and limited availability of clients result in high client-variance. This paper addresses these two issues together by proposing compressed and client-variance reduced methods COFIG and FRECON. We prove an Oâ€‹((1+Ï‰)3/2â€‹NSâ€‹Ïµ2+(1+Ï‰)â€‹N2/3Sâ€‹Ïµ2)ğ‘‚superscript1ğœ”32ğ‘ğ‘†superscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğœ”superscriptğ‘23ğ‘†superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(\frac{(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}}{S\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)N^{2/3}}{S\epsilon^{2}}) bound on the number of communication rounds of COFIG in the nonconvex setting, where Nğ‘N is the total number of clients, Sğ‘†S is the number of clients participating in each round, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is the convergence error, and Ï‰ğœ”\omega is the variance parameter associated with the compression operator. In case of FRECON, we prove an Oâ€‹((1+Ï‰)â€‹NSâ€‹Ïµ2)ğ‘‚1ğœ”ğ‘ğ‘†superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{S\epsilon^{2}}) bound on the number of communication rounds. In the convex setting, COFIG converges within Oâ€‹((1+Ï‰)â€‹NSâ€‹Ïµ)ğ‘‚1ğœ”ğ‘ğ‘†italic-ÏµO(\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{S\epsilon}) communication rounds, which, to the best of our knowledge, is also the first convergence result for compression schemes that do not communicate with all the clients in each round. We stress that neither COFIG nor FRECON needs to communicate with all the clients, and they enjoy the first or faster convergence results for convex and nonconvex federated learning in the regimes considered. Experimental results point to an empirical superiority of COFIG and FRECON over existing baselines.

keywords:
federated learning, distributed optimization, communication compression, variance reduction

1 Introduction

With the proliferation of mobile and edge devices, federated learningÂ [24, 36] has emerged as a framework for training machine learning models over geographically distributed and heterogeneous devices. In federated learning, there is a central server and there are plenty of clients. The central server communicates with the clients to train a machine learning model using the local data stored on the clients. Federated learning is often modeled as a distributed optimization problemÂ [23, 24, 36, 17, 44]. Let ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\mathcal{D}} be the entire dataset distributed across all Nğ‘N clients/devices/workers/machines, where each client iğ‘–i has a local dataset ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\mathcal{D}}_{i}. The goal is to solve the following optimization problem without sharing the local datasets with the central server:

(1) minğ’™âˆˆâ„dâ¡{fâ€‹(ğ’™;ğ’Ÿ):=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfâ€‹(ğ’™;ğ’Ÿi)},subscriptğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘assignğ‘“ğ’™ğ’Ÿ1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ‘“ğ’™subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\displaystyle\min_{{\bm{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left\{f({\bm{x}};{\mathcal{D}}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f({\bm{x}};{\mathcal{D}}_{i})\right\},

where fâ€‹(ğ’™;ğ’Ÿi):=ğ”¼diâˆ¼ğ’Ÿiâ€‹fâ€‹(ğ’™;di)assignğ‘“ğ’™subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ”¼similar-tosubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘“ğ’™subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–f({\bm{x}};{\mathcal{D}}_{i}):=\mathbb{E}_{d_{i}\sim{\mathcal{D}}_{i}}f({\bm{x}};d_{i}). Here, ğ’™âˆˆâ„dğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘{\bm{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is the model, fâ€‹(ğ’™;ğ’Ÿ)ğ‘“ğ’™ğ’Ÿf({\bm{x}};{\mathcal{D}}), fâ€‹(ğ’™;ğ’Ÿi)ğ‘“ğ’™subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–f({\bm{x}};{\mathcal{D}}_{i}), and fâ€‹(ğ’™;di)ğ‘“ğ’™subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–f({\bm{x}};d_{i}) denotes the loss function of the model ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}} on the entire dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\mathcal{D}}, the local dataset ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\mathcal{D}}_{i}, and a random data sample disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d_{i}, respectively.

1.1 Communication efficiency

Communication between the central server and the clients is a main bottleneck for the federated learning applications, especially when the number of clients is large, the clients such as mobile phones have limited bandwidth, and/or the machine learning model has a lot of parameters. Thus, it is crucial to design federated learning algorithms to reduce the overall communication cost, which takes into account both the number of communication rounds and the communication cost per communication round for reaching the desired accuracy. Based on these two quantities, there are two lines of approaches for communication-efficient federated learning: 1) local methods: in each communication round, clients run multiple local update steps before communicating with the central server, hoping to reduce the number of communication rounds; 2) compressed methods: clients send compressed communication messages to the central server, in the hope of reducing the communication cost per communication round.

Both categories have gained significant attention. For local methods, a small sample of examples include FedAvgÂ [36], Local-SVRGÂ [10], SCAFFOLDÂ [18] and FedPAGEÂ [48]. On the other hand, many compressed methods are proposed, including but not limited to [1, 22, 37, 14, 31, 33, 9, 4, 34, 42, 35, 47]. In particular, the current state-of-the-art guarantees in convex and nonconvex settings are provided by CANITAÂ [34] and MARINAÂ [9], respectively.

In this paper, we focus on compression to enhance communication efficiency. See SectionÂ 2.2 for more discussions.

1.2 Methods with variance reduction

Variance reduction, or data-variance reduction is a well-studied technique in standard/centralized finite-sum optimization, which aims to achieve a faster convergence rate. There are many optimization algorithms using the variance reduction technique, including SVRGÂ [16, 40], SAGAÂ [6], SCSGÂ [26], SARAHÂ [38], SPIDERÂ [7], SSRGDÂ [27, 32], and PAGEÂ [29, 28]. These algorithms usually compute the stochastic gradients using a subset of data samples (obtain better convergence results) and periodically compute the full gradient using all data samples (reduce data-variance). For example, the convergence result for standard gradient descent (GD) (which always computes full gradients) is Oâ€‹(N/Ïµ2)ğ‘‚ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(N/\epsilon^{2}) in the nonconvex setting, while the variance-reduced methods SARAH/SPIDER/PAGE obtain much better result Oâ€‹(N/Ïµ2)ğ‘‚ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(\sqrt{N}/\epsilon^{2}).

In the federated learning setting, we decompose the data-variance into two parts: the client-variance and the clientsâ€™ local-variance. The client-variance captures the dissimilarity of data stored on different heterogeneous clients, i.e., the variance induced by different datasets ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\mathcal{D}}_{i} (see problem (1)), which is the variance faced by the central server. The local-variance or local-data-variance is induced by the local data samples stored on each client, and it is the data-variance faced by the local clients if they compute local stochastic gradients not local full gradients. We point out that the client-variance is the main issue for federated learning because of the data heterogeneity issue, and even if one can compute the local full gradients using the whole local dataset ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\mathcal{D}}_{i} on each client (i.e., remove the local-variance), the client-variance faced by the central server still exists.

Moreover, directly applying the variance reduction algorithms like SVRG/PAGE in the federated learning has the following drawbacks: (1) These variance-reduced methods usually need to periodically compute the full gradient using all data samples (reduce data-variance), which leads to communication with all clients periodically in the federated learning setting. However, federated learning applications typically involve a lot of clients, for example, Google Keyboard (Gboard)Â [12, 39] involves billions of mobile phones, and thus it is impractical to communicate with all the clients in a communication round to reduce the client-variance. (2) These variance-reduced algorithms do not use communication compression to further reduce the communication cost. On the other hand, the existing communication compression algorithms usually need to communicate with all the clients in each communication round (see TablesÂ 1). Among the compressed algorithms that support partial participation (PP) (do not need to communicate with all clients in each round), previous methods either need to communicate with all the clients (FP) using uncompressed messages periodically (PP-MARINAÂ [9]), or do not enjoy the faster convergence rate of variance reduction (FedGLOMOÂ [5], EF21-PPÂ [8]). Thus, we consider the following natural and important question:

Can we incorporate client-variance reduction with communication compression
in the federated learning setting?

1.3 Our contributions

In this paper, we design COFIG and FRECON algorithms for federated learning. Both algorithms support communication compression and fully partial participation, and achieve the first/faster convergence using client-variance reduction technique (see TableÂ 1) under any heterogeneity. Concretely, we summarize our main contributions as follows:

  1. 1.

    We design COFIG algorithm, which to our best knowledge, is the first algorithm that supports partial participation and communication compression for the general non-strongly convex federated learning setting (see the convex column in TableÂ 1). For the nonconvex setting, COFIG successfully supports communication compression and fully partial participation (PP) (unlike PP-MARINA) and enjoys the convergence speedup (unlike FedGLOMO and EF21-PP) by using client-variance reduction (see the nonconvex column in TableÂ 1). Besides, COFIG also supports the clientâ€™s local-variance (SectionÂ 2.1) and PP simultaneously, which is more practical than other compressed algorithms such as FedGLOMO and PP-MARINA in federated learning.

  2. 2.

    For the nonconvex setting, we further design a new FRECON algorithm based on COFIG, which can converge much faster than COFIG (see the nonconvex column in TableÂ 1). In particular, FRECON converges within Oâ€‹((1+Ï‰)â€‹N/(Sâ€‹Ïµ2))ğ‘‚1ğœ”ğ‘ğ‘†superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O((1+\omega)\sqrt{N}/(S\epsilon^{2})) communication rounds, matches the convergence result of PP-MARINA. However, FRECON supports fully partial participation with a subset clients and thus is more practical than PP-MARINA which requires periodical full participation (FP) with uncompressed messages. Note that periodic FP needs to periodically synchronize all clients/devices in federated learning, which is usually impossible or unaffordable.

3 COFIG: Fast Compressed Algorithm with Variance Reduction

In this section, we present our COFIG algorithm (AlgorithmÂ 1), which supports gradient compression, fully partial participation, and has better convergence results. In SectionÂ 3.1, we introduce our COFIG algorithm, and in SectionÂ 3.2, we present the convergence rate of COFIG in both convex and nonconvex settings.

3.1 COFIG algorithm

In our COFIG algorithm, each client iğ‘–i maintains the local shift sequence {ğ’‰it}superscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\} and a virtual sequence {ğ’˜it}superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡\{{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t}\}111Here, the virtual sequence {ğ’˜it}superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡\{{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t}\} is only used for algorithmic illustration and analysis purpose. In real execution, the clients do not need to maintain {ğ’˜it}superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡\{{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t}\}., and the server maintains the global shift {ğ’‰t}superscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡\{{\bm{h}}^{t}\} and the model ğ’™tsuperscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}^{t} in each round. At a very high-level point of view, the virtual variable ğ’˜itsuperscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t} records the model ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}} in client iğ‘–iâ€™s last active communication round, and the shifts {ğ’‰it}superscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\} are used for reducing the variance.

Now, we describe these ingredients in more detail. COFIG can be divided into three steps: (1) clients compute and compress the local gradient information using the current model ğ’™tsuperscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}^{t} and local shifts {ğ’‰it}superscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\}; (2) clients update the local shift {ğ’‰it+1}superscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡1\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t+1}\} and the virtual sequence {ğ’˜it+1}superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡1\{{\bm{w}}_{i}^{t+1}\}; and (3) the server updates the model to ğ’™t+1superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1{\bm{x}}^{t+1} and the global shift {ğ’‰t+1}superscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡1\{{\bm{h}}^{t+1}\} using the compressed gradient information aggregated from the clients.

In each round tğ‘¡t, the server first sample two sets of clients ğ’®tsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}^{t} and ğ’®~tsuperscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t}. ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’‰it+1]=ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡1absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t+1}]= ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’‰it+Î±â€‹ğ’â€‹(âˆ‡~bâ€‹fiâ€‹(ğ’™t)âˆ’ğ’‰it)]=(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹ğ’‰it+Î±â€‹âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™t).ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ’subscript~âˆ‡ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡1ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ›¼âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}+\alpha{\mathcal{C}}(\tilde{\nabla}_{b}f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})-{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t})]=(1-\alpha){\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}+\alpha\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t}).

This biased shift is useful for controlling the variance.

Then for the clients jâˆˆğ’®~tğ‘—superscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡j\in\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t}, they compute the estimators and send to the server. Note the compressed message ğ’—jtsuperscriptsubscriptğ’—ğ‘—ğ‘¡{\bm{v}}_{j}^{t} computed by clients jâˆˆğ’®~tğ‘—superscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡j\in\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t} is nearly the same as the compressed message ğ’–itsuperscriptsubscriptğ’–ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\bm{u}}_{i}^{t} computed by clients iâˆˆğ’®tğ‘–superscriptğ’®ğ‘¡i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t} except the randomness of compression operator, and we need to compute ğ’—jtsuperscriptsubscriptğ’—ğ‘—ğ‘¡{\bm{v}}_{j}^{t} to decouple the randomness in the nonconvex setting.

Finally, the server updates the model ğ’™tsuperscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}^{t} and the global shift ğ’‰tsuperscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡{\bm{h}}^{t}. From Line 16 of Algorithm AlgorithmÂ 1, it is easy to prove that he global shift ğ’‰tsuperscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡{\bm{h}}^{t} is an average of the local shifts {ğ’‰it}superscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\}. To update the model, the server first computes a gradient estimator ğ’ˆtsuperscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡{\bm{g}}^{t} using the compressed information aggregated from the clients. The estimator ğ’ˆtsuperscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡{\bm{g}}^{t} is an unbiased estimator for âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’™t)âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\nabla f({\bm{x}}^{t}), since

Now we point out COFIG in the degenerated cases: 1) the case with no compression (Ï‰=0ğœ”0\omega=0) and no clientsâ€™ local-variance (âˆ‡~bâ€‹fiâ€‹(ğ’™t)=âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™t)subscript~âˆ‡ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\tilde{\nabla}_{b}f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})=\nabla f_{i}({\bm{x}}^{t})), our COFIG algorithm reduces to the SAGA algorithmÂ [6] for finite-sum optimization; 2) the case with full participation (ğ’®t=ğ’®~t=[N]superscriptğ’®ğ‘¡superscript~ğ’®ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘{\mathcal{S}}^{t}=\tilde{\mathcal{S}}^{t}=[N]), our algorithm reduces to the DIANA algorithmÂ [37, 14]. As a result, our COFIG enhances the SAGA with communication compression, and generalizes the DIANA without requiring full clients participation.

3.2 Convergence results for COFIG

Now we state the convergence results of COFIG in convex setting (TheoremÂ 3.1) and nonconvex setting (TheoremÂ 3.2). These two theorems show that, by incorporating client-variance reduction with communication compression, COFIG obtains faster convergence results (enjoying the speedup from variance reduction techniques) and supports partial participation (thus more practical for federated learning).

Theorem 3.1 (COFIG in convex case).

Suppose that SectionÂ 2.1, SectionÂ 2.1, and SectionÂ 2.1 hold. Theorem 3.2 (COFIG in nonconvex case).

Suppose that SectionÂ 2.1 and SectionÂ 2.1 hold. By choosing Î±=11+Ï‰ğ›¼11ğœ”\alpha=\frac{1}{1+\omega}, and Î·=minâ¡{12â€‹L,S5â€‹Lâ€‹(1+Ï‰)â€‹N2/3,S5â€‹Lâ€‹(1+Ï‰)3/2â€‹N,bâ€‹Sâ€‹Ïµ220â€‹(1+Ï‰)â€‹Ïƒ2}ğœ‚12ğ¿ğ‘†5ğ¿1ğœ”superscriptğ‘23ğ‘†5ğ¿superscript1ğœ”32ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘†superscriptitalic-Ïµ2201ğœ”superscriptğœ2\eta=\min\Big{\{}\frac{1}{2L},\frac{S}{5L(1+\omega)N^{2/3}},\frac{S}{5L(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}},\frac{bS\epsilon^{2}}{20(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}\Big{\}}, COFIGÂ (AlgorithmÂ 1) will find a point xğ‘¥x such that ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–â‰¤Ïµğ”¼normâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±italic-Ïµ\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f({\bm{x}})\right\|\leq\epsilon in the following number of communication rounds

Now we interpret the convergence results in TheoremÂ 3.1 and TheoremÂ 3.2. First in the convex setting (TheoremÂ 3.1), COFIG converges to an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-solution with the following total communication cost Oâ€‹(SÏµ+(1+Ï‰)â€‹NÏµ+(1+Ï‰)â€‹Ïƒ2bâ€‹Ïµ2)ğ‘‚ğ‘†italic-Ïµ1ğœ”ğ‘italic-Ïµ1ğœ”superscriptğœ2ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(\frac{S}{\epsilon}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}{b\epsilon^{2}}), by multiplying the communication rounds Tğ‘‡T by Sğ‘†S. The first two terms in the communication rounds Tğ‘‡T come from the client-variance reduction, and the last term comes from the clientsâ€™ local variance. Note that our COFIG algorithm provides the first convergence result which supports partial participation and communication compression in the convex setting (see TableÂ 1). Moreover, our algorithm support clientsâ€™ local-variance (SectionÂ 2.1), which has more advantages compared with other compressed gradient methods listed in TableÂ 1 and TableÂ 1.

Next in the nonconvex case (TheoremÂ 3.2), COFIG converges to an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-approximate stationary point with the following total communication cost Oâ€‹(SÏµ2+(1+Ï‰)â€‹N2/3Ïµ2+(1+Ï‰)3/2â€‹NÏµ2+(1+Ï‰)â€‹Ïƒ2bâ€‹Ïµ4)ğ‘‚ğ‘†superscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğœ”superscriptğ‘23superscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscript1ğœ”32ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğœ”superscriptğœ2ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ4O(\frac{S}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)N^{2/3}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}{b\epsilon^{4}}). Similar to the convex case, the first two terms come from the client-variance reduction, and the last term comes from the clientsâ€™ local variance. The third term in the convergence rate comes from the analysis of the compression methods, and the similar term also shows up in the convergence rate of DIANA, which is the full participation version of COFIG. When there is no local variance (Ïƒ2=0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}=0), note that except FedGLOMO and PP-MARINA, all other methods in TableÂ 1 need Oâ€‹(N/Ïµ2)ğ‘‚ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(N/\epsilon^{2}) total communication cost, and our COFIG converges in Oâ€‹(N2/3/Ïµ2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘23superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(N^{2/3}/\epsilon^{2}). Although FedGLOMO converges in Sğ‘†\sqrt{S} and PP-MARINA converges in Oâ€‹(N)ğ‘‚ğ‘O(\sqrt{N}), FedGLOMO has a worse dependency on Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon and needs to assume that the individual functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} are lower bounded, and PP-MARINA needs to periodically communicate with all the clients with uncompressed message. Moreover, both FedGLOMO and PP-MARINA do not support clientsâ€™ local-variance, which makes COFIG more flexible/practical for the federated learning setting. In the next section, we introduce another algorithm FRECON (AlgorithmÂ 2) that matches the convergence rate of PP-MARINA in the nonconvex setting, but it does not need to periodically communicate with all of the clients using uncompressed messages unlike PP-MARINA.

Note that by choosing a proper minibatch size bğ‘b, we further improve the convergence rate in terms of the communication rounds when Ïƒğœ\sigma is large. Formally, we have the following corollary.

3.3 Proof sketch and technical novelty

In this part, we highlight our proof sketch and technical novelty, and we focus on the nonconvex setting. Although our COFIG algorithm can be seen as a generalization of both SAGA and DIANA and our convergence results recover the results of both algorithms, the proof of COFIG is totally different and requires new techniques. 4 FRECON: Faster Algorithm in the Nonconvex Setting

In this section, we present another algorithm FRECON described in AlgorithmÂ 2, which can further achieve a faster convergence rate than COFIG in the nonconvex setting when the clientsâ€™ local-variance is small. We present our FRECON algorithm in SectionÂ 4.1 and show the convergence results in SectionÂ 4.2.

4.1 FRECON algorithm

To achieve Oâ€‹(N/Ïµ2)ğ‘‚ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(\sqrt{N}/\epsilon^{2}) total communication cost in the nonconvex setting, most algorithms use the recursive gradient estimator. Among these algorithms, most of them need to periodically compute full gradients to reduce the variance of the gradient estimator, e.g. SARAHÂ [38], PAGEÂ [29], PP-MARINAÂ [9], FedPAGEÂ [48], except ZeroSARAH [30] which never needs to compute the full gradient. The idea of ZeroSARAH is to maintain another unbiased approximate gradient estimator for the full gradient, and update both the biased recursive and unbiased approximate estimators in each round.

In the federated learning setting with communication compression, recall that in the previous section (SectionÂ 3), our COFIG (AlgorithmÂ 1) can also generate approximate full gradient estimator ğ’ˆtsuperscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡{\bm{g}}^{t} (Line 14 of AlgorithmÂ 1) without communicating with all the clients, the idea of FRECON (AlgorithmÂ AlgorithmÂ 2) is to incorporate recursive gradient estimator together with COFIG (see LineÂ 12 of AlgorithmÂ 2).

In each round, the server sample a set of clients ğ’®tsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘¡{\mathcal{S}}^{t} to communicate with, and the clients iâˆˆğ’®tğ‘–superscriptğ’®ğ‘¡i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t} compute two compressed messages, the first ğ’’itsuperscriptsubscriptğ’’ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\bm{q}}_{i}^{t} is the compressed message for the recursive gradient estimator (Line 5 of AlgorithmÂ 2), and the second ğ’–itsuperscriptsubscriptğ’–ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\bm{u}}_{i}^{t} is the compressed message to update the local shift ğ’‰isubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–{\bm{h}}_{i} and the unbiased full gradient estimator (LineÂ 6 of AlgorithmÂ 2). Then, the server computes the gradient estimator (LineÂ 12 of AlgorithmÂ 2) by

ğ’ˆt+1=1Sâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®tğ’’it+(1âˆ’Î»)â€‹ğ’ˆt+Î»â€‹(1Sâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®tğ’–it+ğ’‰t).superscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡11ğ‘†subscriptğ‘–superscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’’ğ‘¡ğ‘–1ğœ†superscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡ğœ†1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘–superscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’–ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡{\bm{g}}^{t+1}=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t}}{\bm{q}}^{t}_{i}+(1-\lambda){\bm{g}}^{t}+\lambda\left(\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t}}{\bm{u}}^{t}_{i}+{\bm{h}}^{t}\right).

Here, the term 1Sâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®tğ’–it+ğ’‰t1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘–superscriptğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’–ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{S}}^{t}}{\bm{u}}^{t}_{i}+{\bm{h}}^{t} is exactly the gradient estimator used in COFIG, and the gradient estimator ğ’ˆtsuperscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡{\bm{g}}^{t} is a biased estimator. Besides updating the gradient estimator, the server and the clients also need to maintain the global and local shifts ğ’‰tsuperscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡{\bm{h}}^{t} and {ğ’‰it}superscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡\{{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}\} similar to COFIG. Similarly, FRECON with no compression (Ï‰=0ğœ”0\omega=0) and no clientsâ€™ local-variance reduces to the ZeroSARAH algorithmÂ [30].

4.2 Convergence results for FRECON

Now we state the convergence result for FRECON in the nonconvex setting.

Theorem 4.1 (FRECON in nonconvex case).

Suppose that SectionÂ 2.1 and SectionÂ 2.1 hold. By choosing Î±=11+Ï‰ğ›¼11ğœ”\alpha=\frac{1}{1+\omega}, Î·â‰¤1Lâ€‹(1+10â€‹(1+Ï‰)2â€‹N/S2)ğœ‚1ğ¿110superscript1ğœ”2ğ‘superscriptğ‘†2\eta\leq\frac{1}{L(1+\sqrt{10(1+\omega)^{2}N/S^{2}})}, and the minibatch size bâ‰¥Oâ€‹((1+Ï‰)2â€‹Nâ€‹Ïƒ2S2â€‹Ïµ2)ğ‘ğ‘‚superscript1ğœ”2ğ‘superscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘†2superscriptitalic-Ïµ2b\geq O(\frac{(1+\omega)^{2}N\sigma^{2}}{S^{2}\epsilon^{2}}), FRECON (AlgorithmÂ 2) will find a point xğ‘¥x such that ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–â‰¤Ïµğ”¼normâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±italic-Ïµ\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f({\bm{x}})\right\|\leq\epsilon in the following number of communication rounds

T=Oâ€‹(LÏµ2+(1+Ï‰)â€‹NSâ€‹Ïµ2).ğ‘‡ğ‘‚ğ¿superscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğœ”ğ‘ğ‘†superscriptitalic-Ïµ2T=O\left(\frac{L}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{S\epsilon^{2}}\right).

From TheoremÂ 4.1, FRECON enjoys the faster convergence result by the client-variance reduction. The total communication cost of FRECON is Oâ€‹(SÏµ2+(1+Ï‰)â€‹NÏµ2)ğ‘‚ğ‘†superscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğœ”ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(\frac{S}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}), which matches the current state-of-the-art result of PP-MARINA in the nonconvex setting. However, PP-MARINA needs to periodically communicate with all of the clients (FP) with exact information (the uncompressed information), which is impractical in the federated learning setting, while our FRECON only needs to communicate with a subset of clients in every communication round (PP) using compressed messages.

We note that FRECON is not strictly better than COFIG. If there exists clientsâ€™ local-variance, the total communication cost of FRECON is Oâ€‹(SÏµ2+(1+Ï‰)â€‹NÏµ2)ğ‘‚ğ‘†superscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğœ”ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ2O(\frac{S}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}), while COFIG is Oâ€‹(SÏµ2+(1+Ï‰)â€‹N2/3Ïµ2+(1+Ï‰)3/2â€‹NÏµ2+(1+Ï‰)â€‹Ïƒ2bâ€‹Ïµ4)ğ‘‚ğ‘†superscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğœ”superscriptğ‘23superscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscript1ğœ”32ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğœ”superscriptğœ2ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ4O(\frac{S}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)N^{2/3}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}{b\epsilon^{4}}). However,FRECON also needs to sample minibatch stochastic gradients with minibatch size bâ‰¥Oâ€‹((1+Ï‰)2â€‹Nâ€‹Ïƒ2S2â€‹Ïµ2)ğ‘ğ‘‚superscript1ğœ”2ğ‘superscriptğœ2superscriptğ‘†2superscriptitalic-Ïµ2b\geq O(\frac{(1+\omega)^{2}N\sigma^{2}}{S^{2}\epsilon^{2}}) for the communicated clients in each round, while COFIG can adopt minibatch stochastic gradients with size b=1ğ‘1b=1 (but also can use minibatch b>1ğ‘1b>1 to decrease the total communication, see CorollaryÂ 3.3). As a result, the stochastic gradient complexity for FRECON is Oâ€‹((1+Ï‰)â€‹NÏµ2+(1+Ï‰)â€‹Nâ€‹Ïƒ2Ïµ4)ğ‘‚1ğœ”ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğœ”ğ‘superscriptğœ2superscriptitalic-Ïµ4O(\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}\sigma^{2}}{\epsilon^{4}}) by optimizing Sğ‘†S to be (1+Ï‰)â€‹N1ğœ”ğ‘(1+\omega)\sqrt{N}, and for COFIG is Oâ€‹((1+Ï‰)â€‹N2/3Ïµ2+(1+Ï‰)3/2â€‹NÏµ2+(1+Ï‰)â€‹Ïƒ2Ïµ4)ğ‘‚1ğœ”superscriptğ‘23superscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscript1ğœ”32ğ‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ21ğœ”superscriptğœ2superscriptitalic-Ïµ4O(\frac{(1+\omega)N^{2/3}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)^{3/2}\sqrt{N}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{(1+\omega)\sigma^{2}}{\epsilon^{4}}) by choosing Sâ‰¤(1+Ï‰)â€‹N2/3ğ‘†1ğœ”superscriptğ‘23S\leq(1+\omega)N^{2/3}.

5 Numerical Experiments

In this section, we show our numerical experiment results.

5.1 General setup

We run experiments on two problems: logistic regression with a nonconvex regularizerÂ [45, 48] using the a9a datasetÂ [3] and training ResNet-18 neural networkÂ [13] using the CIFAR10 dataset [25].

For logistic regression with a nonconvex regularizer problem, followingÂ [45, 48], the objective function for a sample (ğ’‚,b)ğ’‚ğ‘({\bm{a}},b) is defined as

fâ€‹(ğ’™;(ğ’‚,b))=logâ¡(1+expâ¡(âˆ’bâ€‹ğ’‚âŠ¤â€‹ğ’™))+Î±â€‹âˆ‘j=1dxj21+xj2,ğ‘“ğ’™ğ’‚ğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ’‚topğ’™ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—21superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—2f({\bm{x}};({\bm{a}},b))=\log\left(1+\exp(-b{\bm{a}}^{\top}{\bm{x}})\right)+\alpha\sum\limits_{j=1}^{d}\frac{x_{j}^{2}}{1+x_{j}^{2}},

where the last term is the nonconvex regularizer and we choose Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 in the convex experiments and Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 in the nonconvex experiments.

In the convex experiments (logistic regression), we compare COFIG with DIANA and EF21-PP. We include EF21-PP since we want to compare with some algorithms with partial participation, although it does not have convex analysis. In the logistic regression with nonconvex regularizer, we compare COFIG, FRECON with DIANA, EF21-PP, and PP-MARINA. In the previous experiments, we compute the local full gradient (Ïƒ=0ğœ0\sigma=0), use the theoretical learning rate, and use Natural compression operatorÂ [15] for different algorithms. Besides, we also sort the dataset to simulate the data heterogeneous setting. In the deep learning experiments, we run EF21 instead of DIANA,222We can get the hyperparameters for EF21, e.g., the learning rates, from the original paper. and we estimate the local gradient using a minibatch (Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0). Besides, we tune the learning rate to get the best convergence performance and use random sparsification compressorÂ [46] for all algorithms in the deep learning experiment.

5.2 Binary classification with convex/nonconvex loss

In this experiment, we compare different algorithms under the theoretical step size. We consider both the convex and nonconvex problems.

Problem formulation

For logistic regression with a nonconvex regularizer problem, followingÂ [45, 48], the objective function for a sample (ğ’‚,b)ğ’‚ğ‘({\bm{a}},b) is defined as

fâ€‹(ğ’™;(ğ’‚,b))=logâ¡(1+expâ¡(âˆ’bâ€‹ğ’‚âŠ¤â€‹ğ’™))+Î±â€‹âˆ‘j=1dxj21+xj2,ğ‘“ğ’™ğ’‚ğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ’‚topğ’™ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—21superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—2f({\bm{x}};({\bm{a}},b))=\log\left(1+\exp(-b{\bm{a}}^{\top}{\bm{x}})\right)+\alpha\sum\limits_{j=1}^{d}\frac{x_{j}^{2}}{1+x_{j}^{2}},

where the last term is the nonconvex regularizer. We choose Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 in the convex experiments and the problem becomes the classical logistic regression, and Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 in the nonconvex experiments.

Computing environment

The target machine in which we have launched experiments has Intel(R) Xeon(R) Gold 6246 CPU 3.30GHz with 48 logical cores with hyper-threading and also equipped with two GeForce RTX 3090 GPU cards where each GPU has 5248 scalar FPU cores working at 1.71GHz. Each GeForce RTX 3090 GPU card has 24 GBytes of GPU DRAM memory. We conduct our experiments using the simulation framework FL_PYTorchÂ [2] and implement EF21-PP, MARINA-PP, COFIG, and FRECON.

Description of datasets

In the following experiments, we analyze algorithmsâ€™ performance by regularized logistic regression on several LIBSVMÂ Â [3] datasets: a9a, w8a, phishing, and mushroom. The numbers of optimization variables for these datasets are as follow: 125125125 for a9a, 302302302 for w8a, 707070 for phishing, and 114114114 for mushroom. To simulate the FL settings with different data distribution, we consider two strategies: (i) uniform shuffling, where the considered datasets are randomly shuffled divided into N=100ğ‘100N=100 parts (N=100ğ‘100N=100 clients); and (ii) class-based sorting, where the datasets are sorted based on the label and divided into N=100ğ‘100N=100 parts (that is, 50 clients hold the data with label 111 and other 50 clients hold the data with label 00).

Description of experiments

For non-convex loss experiment we set Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 and we have compared COFIG, FRECON with PP-MARINAÂ [9], DIANAÂ [37, 14], EF21-PPÂ [8]. In these experiments we have selected maximum allowable step size according to the theory of these methods in non-convex regimes. For convex loss experiments set Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 in and use convex theory of DIANA and COFIG to obtain theoretical step sizes. For EF21-PP in the (convex) logistic regression, we use its nonconvex theoretical step size since it does not have convergence analysis under the convex setting. For EF21-PP, COFIG, FRECON, and PP-MARINA in each round we sampled 101010 clients uniformly from 100100100 total clients. For DIANA, the number of clients in each round is 100100100 since it requires full participation. All algorithms run for 10â€‰0001000010\,000 rounds. The amount of communication bits includes the amount of bits from Nğ‘N clients to the master. We use Natural compressorÂ [15] as a compression mechanism used for the communication from clients to server. In these logistic regression (and its variants) experiments, we let each client to compute the local full gradient (Ïƒ=0ğœ0\sigma=0). TableÂ 2 summarizes the experiments settings and their corresponding results.

Experiment results

The results for Experiment #1 are presented in FigureÂ 1. From the results, COFIG and FRECON outperform EF21-PP and DIANA, and are competitive against MARINA-PP with respect to the communication bits. From these experiments, we claim that COFIG, as a generalization of DIANA, behaves better than original DIANA. Although FRECON behaves slightly worse than PP-MARINA, but itâ€™s important to mention that PP-MARINA need to communicate with all clients with uncompressed information periodically, and maybe impossible in practice. Results of Experiment #2 are presented in FigureÂ 2. Although this setting is harder than the previous Experiment #1, all observations and claims made for Experiment #1 almost hold for Experiment #2. Experiments #3 and #4 demonstrate that COFIG in convex setting is practically superior than EF21-PP, DIANA in all considered LIBSVM datasets. (See FigureÂ 3 and FigureÂ 4). The class-based sorting setting for binary classification if the number of clients is even and each client has the same number of datapoint will essentially mean that each client has training samples corresponding only to one class. Without collaboration with other clients and using only local data points the training process organized through optimization of fiâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥f_{i}(x) is meaningless for any client iğ‘–i, and we want to highlight that in this extreme case, collaboration between clients is required.

5.3 Image classification with neural nets

In this experiment we train ResNet-18Â [13] on the CIFAR10 dataset [25]. The dimension of optimization problem d=11â€‰173â€‰962ğ‘‘11173962d=11\,173\,962, from which 11â€‰159â€‰2321115923211\,159\,232 optimization variables come from training parameters of cross correlation operators Conv2d, 9â€‰60096009\,600 optimization variables comes from training Batch Normalization layers, and finally, 5â€‰13051305\,130 optimization variables come from training last linear FC layer.

The sizes of the training and validation set are 50â€‹K50ğ¾50K and 10â€‹K10ğ¾10K records. Similar to the heterogeneous binary classification experiments, the CIFAR10 dataset has been partitioned heterogeneously across 101010 clients, where each client contains the data of a single class and there are 10 classes in total (i.e., class-based sorting).

Problem formulation

We define fiâ€‹(ğ’™)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™f_{i}({\bm{x}}) to be local empirical risk associated with the local data, ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–{\mathcal{D}}_{i} stored on client iğ‘–i. Here a(j)âˆˆâ„3Ã—28Ã—28superscriptğ‘ğ‘—superscriptâ„32828a^{(j)}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 28\times 28} is input image, b(j)âˆˆ{e1,â€¦,e10}superscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘’1â€¦subscriptğ‘’10b^{(j)}\in\{e_{1},\dots,e_{10}\} is one one-hot encoding of class label, Ni=|ğ’Ÿi|subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–N_{i}=|{\mathcal{D}}_{i}|, and gğ‘”g is a neural networks parameterized by unknown variable ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}}. Description of experiment

In this experiment, we random shuffle the CIFAR10 dataset to avoid the problematic behavior of Batch Normalization in ResNet-18. The step sizes for different algorithms are tuned from the following set Lâ€‹Rsâ€‹eâ€‹tğ¿subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘¡{LR}_{set} to get fastest convergence:

(8) Lâ€‹Rsâ€‹eâ€‹t=ğ¿subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘’ğ‘¡absent\displaystyle{LR}_{set}= {0.1,0.06,0.03,0.01,0.006,0.003,0.001,0.0006,\displaystyle\{0.1,0.06,0.03,0.01,0.006,0.003,0.001,0.0006,
0.0003,0.0001,0.00006,0.00003,0.00001}.\displaystyle\quad 0.0003,0.0001,0.00006,0.00003,0.00001\}.

In this experiment, we compare EF21, EF21-PP, COFIG, FRECON, and PP-MARINA. We divide the dataset into 101010 parts (N=10ğ‘10N=10 clients), and each client holds 500050005000 samples. For EF21-PP, COFIG, FRECON, and PP-MARINA, we test both cases for S=1ğ‘†1S=1 and S=2ğ‘†2S=2. We use the RandKÂ [46] compressor with K=0.05â€‹Dğ¾0.05ğ·K=0.05D for all algorithms, where Dğ·D is the number of parameters for ResNet-18. Unlike the previous binary classification experiments, in this deep learning experiments, different algorithms cannot access the local full gradients from the clients (Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0). When the algorithms need the local full gradients, each client estimates the gradient using a minibatch with size b=500ğ‘500b=500 (10%percent1010\% of the local data).

Experiment results

The results for this image classification deep learning experiments are presented in FigureÂ 5 and FigureÂ 6 with S=1ğ‘†1S=1 and S=2ğ‘†2S=2, respectively. In our experiments, we observe that PP-MARINA is practically impossible in those circumstances. Besides, the performance of FRECON is similar to EF21-PP, and our COFIG converges fastest among all these algorithms. For FRECON we have tuned parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda from trying several values in [0,1]01[0,1] we have found that for training this NN the value Î»=0.75ğœ†0.75\lambda=0.75 leads to more fast convergence. In FigureÂ 7 there is a comparison with full participated version EF21, and our COFIG converges faster as well in terms of the communication bits.

We attribute the results to the fact that COFIG works better with local variance (SectionÂ 2.1) compared with FRECON. It is also worth noting that based on our hyperparameter search, we observe that for FRECON, S=1ğ‘†1S=1 (FigureÂ 5) can use a larger learning rate than S=2ğ‘†2S=2 (FigureÂ 6), which reflect that FRECON may not work very well or unstable when the local variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} (SectionÂ 2.1) is somewhat large. Besides, EF21-PP, FRECON, and COFIG all perform better than the full participation algorithm EF21 in terms of the communicate bits (FigureÂ 7), which shows that partial participation may indeed speed up the convergence in terms of the total communication bits.

This experiment shows that when the number of local data is large, and we can not compute the local full gradient, COFIG may behave best. Together with the previous experiments, COFIG can be set up as a default optimization algorithm for federated learning applications, and then divert to FRECON if we have further information, e.g., we can compute the local full gradient and/or the number of clients is very large.

5.4 Remarks for experiments

According to both logistic regression (with nonconvex regularizer) and the image classification deep learning experiments, we validate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithms COFIG and FRECON. However, the algorithms still have their own advantages in different settings. In short, we summarize the following messages:

  1. 1.

    For problems where we can estimate the local gradients fairly accurately (i.e., the local variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is small), FRECON performs better than COFIG in terms of the communication bits. This trend is also corroborated by the faster theoretical convergence rate of FRECON when Ïƒ2=0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}=0 (TheoremÂ 4.1).

  2. 2.

    When optimizing large-scale neural networks like ResNet that has a relatively large local variance , COFIG performs better than FRECON in terms of the communication bits. This trend is supported by the convergence results of COFIG and FRECON (Theorem 3.2 and 4.1), where COFIG has a smaller dependency with respect to Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} than FRECON. The large dependency on Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} may incur some unstable behaviors when training large neural networks.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we introduce COFIG and FRECON, which successfully incorporate communication compression with client-variance reduction for dealing with large number of heterogeneous clients in federated learning. Our FRECON obtains the best communication complexity for federated nonconvex setting, and our COFIG gives the first theoretical convergence result for federated non-strongly convex setting that supports both communication compression and partial participation, while previous works either obtain worse convergence results or require full clients communication.
